title: When KaBum! beat Alliance - Did this increase domestic viewership in Brazil ?
body:
Just wondering, prob need a Rioter to answer.

Basic Theory (working off assumptions so it could be completely wrong)

- Riot builds an international audience in regards to people watching competitive League of Legends

-Riot then seeks to strengthen domestic Esports scenes by implementing native LCS comps for various regions

-However, this international audience is built around a culture of expertise, where the inferiority of a domestic region - in terms of being able to compete against other regions - is fully acknowledged.

-This acknowledgement of inferiority by the native audiences acts as a boundary for the development of League as an Esport in their own region   

- NOTE  
Established regions never really had to overcome this hurdle because they developed alongside Leagues growth, where newer regions are trying to develop in the shadows of these already established regions and thus the problem of acknowledged inferiority by native audiences is actually quite a new hurdle that has to be overcome to assist in developing Esports in these new regions.  

-However, KaBum! beating Alliance works to off-set this notion of acknowledged inferiority and my assumption is that it could of led to an increase in viewership for Brazil's domestic competition. 

All speculation. Thinking out loud but I am curious if there is any truth to any of this.
